name: Hemingway - Hills Like White Elephants
body:
The hills across the valley of the Ebro were
long and white. On this side there was no
shade and no trees and the station was between
two lines of rails in the sun. Close against the
side of the station there was the warm shadow
of the building and a curtain, made of strings of
bamboo beads, hung across the open door into
the bar, to keep out flies. The American and
the girl with him sat at a table in the shade,
outside the building. It was very hot and the
express from Barcelona would come in forty
minutes. It stopped at this junction for two
minutes and went on to Madrid.
âWhat should we drink?â the girl asked.
She had taken off her hat and put it on the

âItâs pretty hot,â the man said.
âLetâs drink beer.â
âDos cervezas,â the man said into the curtain.
âBig ones?â a woman asked from the doorway.
âYes. Two big ones.â
The woman brought two glasses of beer and
two felt pads. She put the felt pads and the

and the girl. The girl was looking off at the

the country was brown and dry.
âThey look like white elephants,â she said.
âIâve never seen one,â the man drank his

âTheyâve painted something on it,â she said.
âWhat does it say?â

âCould we try it?â
The man called âListenâ through the curtain.

âFour reales.â
âWe want two Anis del Toro.â
âWith water?â
âDo you want it with water?â
âI donât know,â the girl said. âIs it good
with water?â
âItâs all right.â
âYou want them with water?â asked the

âYes, with water.â
âIt tastes like licorice,â the girl said and put

âThatâs the way with everything.â
âYes,â said the girl. âEverything tastes of

âOh, cut it out.â
âYou started it,â the girl said. âI was being
amused. I was having a fine time.â
âWell, letâs try and have a fine time.â
âAll right. I was trying. I said the mountains

âThat was bright.â
âI wanted to try this new drink. Thatâs all

âI guess so.â
The girl looked across at the hills.
âTheyâre lovely hills,â she said. âThey
donât really look like white elephants. I just

âShould we have another drink?â
âAll right.â
The warm wind blew the bead curtain against
the table.
âThe beerâs nice and cool,â the man said.
âItâs lovely,â the girl said.
âItâs really an awfully simple operation, Jig,â
the man said. âItâs not really an operation at

The girl looked at the ground the table legs

âI know you wouldnât mind it, Jig. Itâs

The girl did not say anything.
âIâll go with you and Iâll stay with you all

âThen what will we do afterward?â
âWeâll be fine afterward. Just like we were

âThatâs the only thing that bothers us. Itâs

The girl looked at the bead curtain, put her

âAnd you think then weâll be all right and

âI know we will. You donât have to be

âSo have I,â said the girl. âAnd afterward

âWell,â the man said, âif you donât want

The girl stood up and walked to the end of

âAnd we could have all this,â she said. âAnd

âWhat did you say?â

âWe can have everything.â
âNo, we canât.â
âWe can have the whole world.â
âNo, we canât.â

âNo, we canât. It isnât ours any more.â
âItâs ours.â
âNo, it isnât. And once they take it away,

âBut they havenât taken it away.â
âWeâll wait and see.â
âCome on back in the shade,â he said. âYou
mustnât feel that way.â
âI donât feel any way,â the girl said. âI
just know things.â
âI donât want you to do anything that you
donât want to doâââ
âNor that isnât good for me,â she said. âI
know. Could we have another beer?â
âAll right. But youâve got to realizeâââ
âI realize,â the girl said. âCanât we maybe

They sat down at the table and the girl
looked across at the hills on the dry side of the

âYouâve got to realize,â he said, âthat I donât

âDoesnât it mean anything to you? We could
get along.â
âOf course it does. But I donât want anybody
but you. I donât want any one else. And
I know itâs perfectly simple.â
âYes, you know itâs perfectly simple.â
âItâs all right for you to say that, but I do

âWould you do something for me now?â
âIâd do anything for you.â
âWould you please please please please

He did not say anything but looked at the

âBut I donât want you to,â he said, âI donât

âIâll scream,â the girl said.
The woman came out through the curtains

âWhat did she say?â asked the girl.
âThat the train is coming in five minutes.â
The girl smiled brightly at the woman, to

âIâd better take the bags over to the other

âAll right. Then come back and weâll finish

He picked up the two heavy bags and carried

Coming back, he walked through the barroom,

He drank an Anis at the bar and looked

âDo you feel better?â he asked.
